Award.AwardTitle: A Focused Student Recruitment and Support Model for Attracting Top Achieving Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will create a Top Achieving Scholars (TAS) program to provide 20 four-year scholarships and 12 three-year scholarship in three cohorts for academically talented and financially needy students in computer engineering, computer science, civil engineering, electrical engineering, manufacturing engineering, and mechanical engineering at The University of Texas-Pan American (UTPA). The goals of the project are to improve educational opportunities for students by coupling student preparation with mentoring, tutoring, and research opportunities; to achieve student academic success and research excellence while providing broad educational access; and to cultivate more Hispanic Engineers by, among other things, increasing retention of students to degree achievement. Proposed efforts include ten different activities and services in recruiting, mentoring and student leadership development. These activities and services will foster students' growth and interest in their fields of study. A unique and valuable aspect of the program is its effort to influence students who are not in the program. This includes providing constructive feedback to applicants who are not selected, and forming learning communities with both TAS and non-TAS students. The requirement that students prepare a professional plan or technical document to share with family and community will also extend the program's reach beyond the funded students. This project would have a direct positive impact on the participation in the STEM fields by Hispanic Americans since the institution is an HSI. This project could provide a model for other underrepresented groups such as African Americans, Native Americans and women in the STEM fields.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UTRGV "Top Achieving Scholars" (TAS) program provided services and activities to student scholars such as community building meetings, mentoring, field trips, and seminars. It worked with academically talented, financially disadvantaged students who were either U.S. citizens or permanent U.S. residents and who qualified to receive financial aid. Mentoring and professional opportunities were integral part of the TAS program since its inception and the UTRGV Center of Excellence in STEM was the dedicated location for several of the services and activities. In addition, a staff member (upper level engineering student) supported the faculty mentoring efforts in the program. Student mentoring was especially important for minority and female students. The scholars were encouraged to participate in information sessions on summer research programs and graduate school with external and internal speakers and were encouraged to get involved in a UTRGV service opportunity. Forty-seven students, from different engineering and computer science majors, participated in and benefited from the TAS program. By the end of the funded program, 23 students graduated from their academic programs and the majority accepted STEM full time jobs and/or went to graduate school. Additional scholars, students who participated in the program, will be graduating in the following semesters.

This project was important to the nation, the region, and UTRGV for several important reasons including the educational trends of Hispanic students, impact on the U.S. workforce, and the ability to transform minority engineering and computer science education across the board. Given the social-economic demographics of the region (e.g. rapidly growing, very young populations, low education attainment, and high poverty rates) there was no better region in the Unites States than the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas to support efforts to increase the knowledge and understanding of effective educational strategies for increasing the participation of underrepresented students. While the UTRGV TAS focused on Engineering and Computer science students, the lessons learned are being applied to different STEM programs.
